explanation:
You must know the semantics of the following symbols to decide whether any controlling expression in lfs_fs_deorphan can be invariant (i.e. always true/false) or whether it can change during execution: 

- lfs_gstate_hasorphans: controls the initial early-return condition (!...); need to know whether it can ever be true/false for given filesystem state.
- lfs_pair_isnull: controls the inner loop while(!lfs_pair_isnull(pdir.tail)); its definition/semantics determine whether the inner loop can terminate for the initialized pdir.tail and values produced by lfs_dir_fetch.
- lfs_dir_fetch: produces the next directory (dir) and its tail; its effects determine how pdir.tail evolves and thus whether the inner loop condition can change.
- lfs_fs_parent: returns tag (or LFS_ERR_NOENT) used in inner branching; its return values affect whether subsequent code (and commits) run and therefore whether loop progress or state changes occur.
- LFS_ERR_NOENT: constant compared to parent tag; required to interpret the parent test and branch behavior.
- lfs_dir_get: reads directory metadata used in comparisons/commits; its outputs affect values tested later and whether commits that change state happen.
- lfs_pair_fromle32: transforms on-disk pair representation before pair comparison; needed because pair comparisons (pair_issync) use the converted values.
- lfs_pair_issync: used to detect desyncs; its result drives an orphan-fixing commit path that can change filesystem state (and set moreorphans).
- lfs_gstate_hasmovehere: used to decide whether to prepare a move (and call lfs_fs_prepmove); affects whether state-mutating actions occur in the desync branch.
- lfs_tag_id: used to extract move id for move handling; its value affects arguments to prepmove/commit and thus could influence state transitions.
- lfs_fs_prepmove: called when a move is detected while fixing orphans; its side-effects may change global state consulted by the loops.
- lfs_pair_tole32: counterpart to fromle32 used before committing; needed to understand what is actually written and how pair values used in comparisons/commits are formed.
- lfs_dir_orphaningcommit: central commit routine; its return value (including LFS_OK_ORPHANED) and side-effects determine whether moreorphans becomes true and whether outer loop restarts or terminates.
- LFS_OK_ORPHANED: return code checked to set moreorphans; needed to know when outer loop resets pass to 0.
- lfs_dir_getgstate: used in the full-orphan branch to "steal" gstate and then commit tail; its behavior affects whether commits occur and whether moreorphans becomes true.
- lfs_fs_preporphans and lfs_gstate_getorphans: used at the final return to mark orphans fixed; gstate_getorphans reports orphan count which is relevant to initial/terminal conditions and to verifying the overall state changes performed.
- lfs_mdir_t (type/fields): the structure fields (split, tail, pair, etc.) are read and written and drive control flow (e.g., the if (!pdir.split) block and how pdir updates affect the inner loop);
- lfs_pair_t / pair representation: representation of tails/pairs (values that pair_isnull/fromle32/ttole32 operate on) is necessary to reason whether tail values can change across iterations and therefore whether pair-based conditions are invariant.

In short: to determine whether any of the controlling expressions (the initial if and the two while loops and the internal ifs comparing tags/pairs) are invariant you must know the semantics, return values, side-effects and relevant constants of the listed functions/types/macros, because many conditions depend on values those symbols produce or on state mutations those symbols perform (not purely on local compile-time constants).
